awd_titl_txt: RUI: Biophysical Characterization of Reduced Flavin-Dependent Two Component Monooxygenase Sulfur Assimilation Enzymes: SfnG, MsuC, and MsuD
awd_abstract_narration:
With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes program is funding Dr. Denyce K. Wicht at Suffolk University and Dr. Daniel P. Dowling at UMass-Boston to research proteins involved in extracting sulfur from naturally occurring organic molecules. The cycling of sulfur-containing substances is important to understanding how living organisms (including humans) play a role in moving this specific element between earth's water, atmosphere, and land components. The interconversions of compounds containing carbon-sulfur bonds and sulfur-oxygen bonds are observed across a range of microorganisms, but the order in which the chemistry proceeds only recently was discovered. Therefore, these chemical transformations remain largely unexplored. This research entails a collaborative effort by Dr. Wicht and Dr. Dowling to perform fundamental biochemical analyses and obtain structural information for how these events take place. Research assistants at the undergraduate and graduate level gain experience with enzymology, biochemistry, and protein crystallography. Additionally, participants engage in outreach activities with middle school students and receive specific feedback on lifelong learning skills important to the production of a modern STEM workforce. Strong scientific mentorship provided by PI Wicht and co-PI Dowling contributes to the development of a diverse, globally competitive STEM workforce. 
 
The recently reported bacterial sulfur assimilation pathway from naturally occurring dimethylsulfone to inorganic sulfite is the central focus of the work. There are three monooxygenases involved in the biochemical reactions: SfnG (for sulfone utilization), MsuC (for methanesulfinate utilization), and MsuD (for methanesulfonate ultilization). All three enzymes are reduced flavin dependent monooxygenases that require three substrates: an organosulfur molecule, O2, and FMNH2. The kinetic landscape of the novel biochemical pathway from dimethylsulfone to sulfite is unknown, therefore the immediate goal of the proposed research activities is the determination of the apparent steady-state kinetic parameters for each protein in the pathway using visible spectroscopy. The kinetic analyses of purified recombinant enzymes are coupled with substrate specificity data determined by 1H and 13C NMR spectroscopy. For each monooxygenase, a maximum rate of enzyme turnover and the specificity constant for the preferred organosulfur substrate is defined. High-resolution X-ray crystallography is used to determine the molecular details of enzyme active site(s) and reaction chemistry. Together, the experimental results are used to formulate a proposed overall enzyme mechanism consistent with the cleavage of two C-S bonds and the formation of one S-O bond. Mapping the active site environment of these enzymes guides future mechanistic studies by identifying important amino acid residues involved in bond-making and bond-breaking to sulfur.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Project Title: Research at Undergraduate Institutions: Biophysical Characterization of Reduced Flavin-Dependent Two Component Monooxygenase Sulfur Assimilation Enzymes: SfnG, MsuC, and MsuD

 

Summary:

We biochemically and structurally characterized the three monooxygenases from Pseudomonas fluorescens that are responsible for the conversion of dimethylsulfone (DMSO2), a ubiquitous organosulfur compound in nature, to methanesulfinate, methanesulfonate, and sulfite. The monooxygenases SfnG, MsuC, and MsuD function in P. fluorescens and related Pseudomonads within the sulfur assimilation pathway when sulfate is limiting in the environment. We successfully produced recombinant proteins that were functional enzymes for assays and structural characterization by X-ray crystallography. We characterized the binding of oxidized FMN to each monooxygenase, SfnG, MsuC, and MsuD, as well as to their two-component related flavin reductase, MsuE. Our results revealed that the monooxygenases all bind oxidized flavin with Kd values greater than 1 μM, whereas the flavin reductase binds FMN with a Kd value <1 μM, consistent with tight binding. These results are consistent with the role of MsuE in reducing FMN in an NADH-dependent manner to generated reduced flavin for the three monooxygenases. We solved the first crystal structures of SfnG to 2.6 angstrom resolution (unliganded state) and to 1.7 angstrom resolution (with FMN and DMSO2 bound). The structures revealed how the ligands FMN and DMSO2 are bound and selected for, as well as identified flexible areas of the protein that become ordered upon ligand binding. We solved the first crystal structure of MsuC to 1.7 angstrom resolution, confirming MsuC as a class D flavoprotein monooxygenase. Our studies elucidated MsuC as a methanesulfinate monooxygenase, assigning its biochemical function within the DMSO2 utilization pathway of Pseudomonads. We solved the first crystal structures of MsuD to between 2.4-2.8 angstrom resolutions, in multiple liganded states. These structures reveal how the ligands FMN and methanesulfonate bind to MsuD. The active site is particularly large in comparison to the small, tetrahedral molecule of methanesulfonate, which led us to pursue substrate specificity experiments with variable alkanesulfonates. Our work revealed that MsuD from P. fluorescens shows activity with C1, C5, and C8 length alkanesulfonates, therefore we reassigned MsuD from P. fluorescens as a small to medium-chain alkanesulfonate monooxygenase. Our structural studies further identified a novel use of the protein tetramer to both close the enzyme active site and provide residues that interact with the sulfonate-binding residues. Deletion of these residues led to an enzyme that no longer formed a tetramer by size-exclusion chromatography, and the activity was decreased against methanesulfonate in comparison to the wild type enzyme. These results have expanded support for the number of  enzymes that likely proceed using an N5-(hydro)peroxyflavin intermediate. Both SfnG and MsuD are now predicted to proceed through the N5-(hydro)peroxyflavin intermediate, consistent with how ligands are bound within their crystal structures and the predicted oxygen binding sites. MsuC appears to be a traditional monooxygenase that likely proceeds using C4a flavin chemistry. These studies have set the stage for future work to explore the newly revealed intricacies of these systems.

 

These studies resulted in the training of four undergraduate researchers at Suffolk University, two undergraduate researchers at UMass Boston, one undergraduate researcher shared between Suffolk University and UMass Boston, one Masters student at UMass Boston, and three Ph.D. graduate students at UMass Boston. Five students were women, and one student was from an underrepresented minority group in the sciences. This work supported STEM outreach events with the McCormack Middle School, a Boston Public Middle School that works with a diverse student body. This outreach provided a mechanism for 6th, 7th, and 8th graders to interact with undergraduate and graduate students from UMass Boston and undergraduate students from Suffolk University to learn about college, learn from students who chose to study science, and perform science-related activities. Outreach events occurred at both the McCormack Middle School and at UMass Boston. This work has set the stage for a continued Partnership between UMass Boston and the McCormack Middle School science teachers to perform outreach events each year.
